Tucson embraces Talon with his tail around her shoulders.

" So will I. Tal=
on, so will I.  But that doesn't mean we can't try to recreate a little por=
tion of life on our own planet.  This seed we were given, it needs soil, wa=
ter, light and something to plant it in.  Perhaps we can find a place where=
 there is an abundance of soil and take that with us. "

Just as he spoke, =
a Protohuman, carrying an offering of fish, kneels down before Tucson and T=
alon.  Tucson looks to the offering.  It was a most generous portion of fis=
h.  Yet now he could not eat it, but he knew Talon would need nourishment. =
 He nods gently to the Protohuman and accepts his offering with a gentile t=
ouch of his nose on the man's shoulder.  He allows him to stroke his snout =
as some sort of good luck ritual.  The man bows in graciousness to Tucson's=
 gesture of kindness and leaves him be with Talon.

" I'm not so sure what =
all of that meant but, whatever it was, it was a very kind  gesture on his =
part.  I wonder if these people had any interaction with the old Silver Dra=
gon.. " 

It isn't long before others come to offer more gifts to him and T=
alon.  One of the Protohumans points to a painting on a rock, with white po=
rtraying silver, in a primitive image of a large reptile with outstretched =
wings.

" Oh, I see now..  Yes, they have seen him before.  To them he is a=
 guardian, and the more offerings they gave him, he would return their kind=
 gestures by offering his protection.  But there is more to these paintings=
..  A strange mysterious figure, with an aura around it..  To me it seems e=
vil.  Another idol, someone else to worship. ..  People portrayed in black =
and white..  White, meaning those who look to the Silver Dragon and black t=
o those who worship the intimidating idol..  I've seen ancient pictographs =
before on Cybertron, and these are different but in the same format. Talon =
if the dragon is a physical being, then this dark idol must be as well.  We=
 need to find it, before it lays harm to anyone."

ntively and at that moment, the creature lifts its head. It was another dra=

oks to her. She slowly approaches him and they look gently to each other li=
ke brother and sister. In draconic vocalization, Tucson explains who he is =
and his dilemma.  She intern rumbles back and bows her head. She nods as he=
 does. It was their way of communicating as Tucson looks back to Talon.

 along with her brethren for as long as they live. And she wishes us good l=
uck on our journey."
